group_1.narration: This is when we had been living@in the nunnery for a while.
It was when Dolma suddenly said@something like this.

group_1.textRight: I... I'm going to become a Rakshasi.

group_1.textLeft: ...Dolma?

group_1.textRight: Yes.
So... Heruka, you don't have to@worry anymore.
Just leave everything to me.

group_1.narration: A Rakshasi was originally considered an evil demon,@a kind of monster that leads people astray,@but now we're taught that it's a guardian deity.
Well, I'm not entirely sure, but it must@be a precious and special existence.
The Rakshasi is said to lie beneath this land in Tibet.
In other words, it sacrificed itself to lay@the foundation of Tibet, bringing paradise...@Shambhala to this land.
So...@If we're going to build a new foundation for Tibet,@which was ravaged by the Mongol Empire,@it has to be the Rakshasi.
Everyone believes that, but...@it's a sacrifice.

group_1.textLeft: When we talk about sacrifice here...
It means...dedicating one's life to saving@Tibet and its people...
That's the interpretation we have.

group_1.textRight: Dedicate one's life...

group_1.textLeft: In any case, through the Rakshasi ritual,
you won't become a Rakshasi unless you're@chosen by Lord Jataka.
Strive in your training to be recognized@by him, Heruka.

group_1.narration: I never intended to work hard in my training.
Even if someone becomes a special existence,@there's no way we can defeat the powerful@Mongolian Army.

group_1.textLeft: ...Dolma has been standing under the waterfall@for a long time...

group_1.textRight: Such concentration...

group_1.textLeft: Dolma, from now on, should we...
...study together?

group_1.textRight: It's time for practice.
By working hard during this time,@I can gain an advantage.

group_1.textLeft: I see.
Haha... Should I study too?

group_1.textRight: Heruka, you don't have to.@Just play.

group_1.textLeft: But...

group_1.textRight: It's okay, really.@You don't have to work hard anymore.

group_1.textLeft: I don't have to work hard...

group_1.textRight: ...What are you doing?

group_1.textLeft: Oh... Lama.
Dolma told me to play outside...
But I can't really get into the mood for that,@so I was thinking about something.

group_1.textRight: Thinking about what...?

group_1.textLeft: What is a Rakshasi, after all...?

group_1.textRight: Simply put, it's someone who saves everyone.
By receiving Buddha's blessings, they can also@unleash tremendous power.

group_1.textLeft: ...Has anyone ever become a Rakshasi?

group_1.textRight: Yes.
When the Mongolian Army attacked...@around that time.

group_1.textLeft: What happened to that person...?
...I heard there are other nunneries@besides this one.
So, the Rakshasis have been chosen from@other nunneries too...
...What happened to everyone?
They died, didn't they...?

group_1.textRight: Those who couldn't reach true Rakshasi status...@that's what happened.

group_1.textLeft: It's sophistry, isn't it?
...In the end, it's all in vain.
Even if someone becomes a Rakshasi,@we can't defeat the Mongolian Army.
We can't save everyone...

group_1.textRight: ...Heruka, there are many blue flowers@blooming in this nunnery...
Would you be willing to take care of them?

group_1.textLeft: ...Why do you ask?

group_1.textRight: Because I want you to develop some attachment@to this nunnery, even if it's just a little.

group_1.textLeft: Encouraging attachment, huh...@That's quite unusual.

group_1.textRight: Indeed, from the perspective of teachings,@it may seem so...
But a life solely devoted to teachings@can be dull...

group_1.narration: I had a vague sense of it.
Since that time, the Lama has been opposing@the Rakshasi ritual, and...
